markdownRemark.html:
Score: 72.5

wonkette.com  (WEB - en-US)

An online political and cultural magazine that lampoons Republicans and conservatives.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Rebecca Schoenkopf, a longtime Los Angeles journalist, is owner and publisher of Wonkette. The site started as a Gawker Media blog in 2004 but was dropped in 2008. Schoenkopf purchased the site in March 2012. Wonkette is funded by reader donations and does not run advertisements.

Content

Wonkette publishes satirical, strongly opinionated commentary about news, American politics, and culture. It criticizes Republican and conservative politicians. Stories and headlines may include profanity. It attempts biting humor on sensitive topics such as sexual assault and racism. For example, “Don Jr. Terrified of Day When Trump Men Might Not Be Allowed To Be Gross and Rapey,” mocked the president’s son after he voiced concern that his own sons would one day be wrongly accused of sexual assault. Other stories in the News section include: “Putin Invites Trump To Moscow For Season Two of ‘50 Shades Of Pee.’”

The Culture section includes topics such as Culture Wars and Journamalism, which satirize mainstream media and highlight cultural divisions within America. Wonkette provides coverage of gender, race, science, and religion. Political content is found in all of the sections.

Credibility

Wonkette staff and contributors produce content often loosely based on a fact or news story, with clear sourcing and links to where information originated. Wonkette often cites established sources, such as The Associated Press, while providing commentary.

Headlines are often satirical, sarcastic, and may include profanity. A story on a decision of a North Dakota senator to vote against Brett Kavanaugh’s Supreme Court confirmation was titled, “Heidi Heitkamp Not Voting For Quaaludes McRapeVan, Because F--- You Is Why.” Other headlines from 2018 include “For Once, a Chicago cop was found guilty of murder,” “I Am An Italian-American And I Think Columbus Day Is Garbage,” and “Wall Street Journal Sooo Bored By Donald Trump’s Itty-Bitty Massive Tax Fraud.”

Because Wonkette’s hyper-partisan and sarcastic opinions are mixed with news stories, and because Wonkette tags its site “Independent News,” NewsGuard has determined that Wonkette does not handle the difference between news and opinion responsibly, or avoid deceptive headlines. When asked how readers should view content on Wonkette, Schoenkopf told NewsGuard in an email:

“We are a news site. All our posts -- every story -- are factual and backed by links to mainstream sources. I'm also quick to correct when we do jump the gun on breaking news, or misinterpret something. The news is also informed by our expertise and institutional memory. We don't just regurgitate what we read one day; we have long memories (decades' worth) and use them to enrich our readers' understanding of each discrete news item.”

When asked about its policy for headlines, Schoenkopf said, “the only rule is they have to be funny. No, funnier than that. No, FUNNIER.”

Wonkette does not state a corrections policy, but NewsGuard has found examples of corrected stories.

Transparency

Wonkette names and provides information about senior staff, editors, and most authors, although some use pseudonyms such as Five Dollar Feminist and Wonderbitch. Because the site regularly features pseudonymous authors, NewsGuard has determined that Wonkette does not provide information about content creators.

Asked why Wonkette allows pseudonyms and whether their use impacts credibility, Schoenkopf told NewsGuard, “ I don't think it particularly affects our credibility; I know who the writers are and they have the expertise they're claiming.” Schoenkopf  added, “I've met all of them in person even, except Wonderbitch since she lives in Alaska.”

The site states clearly that it is financed by readers.

History

Wonkette was founded in 2004 by Ana Marie Cox, a political columnist and culture critic who has also worked at the New York Times Magazine and Gawker Media. In 2004 Wonkette broke the story of Jessica Cutler, a staff assistant of then-Democratic U.S. Senator Mike DeWine of Ohio, who authored an anonymous blog, “The Washingtonienne,” which detailed her sex life with powerful men in Washington D.C.

In 2011, Wonkette lost numerous advertisers after an author mocked former Alaska Governor Sarah Palin’s son, Trig Palin, who has Down Syndrome. Wonkette issued an apology, but ultimately the story was removed. Schoenkopf told NewsGuard in an email that “ the previous owner sold it [Wonkette] to me in 2012 probably because of fallout from the Trig post. Our ad revenues quadrupled over the next several years.”

But, she said, Wonkette “gave up ads in February 2017” because the “bottom fell out of the ad market...Now we're funded entirely by reader donations, by about 4000 people a month.”

Written by:
Evan Haddad

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Jim Warren
